newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Stals sees signs of S.African economic recovery.
newsitem.headline: Stals sees signs of S.African economic recovery.

text.p: Reserve Bank Governor Chris Stals said on Friday there were signs the economic slowdown was over and South Africa could have its fourth year in a row of around three percent growth in 1997.

"Normally one would have expected after three-and-a-half years of economic expansion that the business cycle will turn, that economic activities will decline... that you will go through almost a recessionary period," Stals told the parliamentary finance committee.
"We've had a slow down in growth for about six or nine months and... we are already at this stage seeing some signs of recovery and improvement," he said.
"So maybe we can have this kind of three to three-and-a- half percent growth for the fourth year in succession in 1997 and in 1997 it will be more balanced growth also...
"We feel fairly comfortable about prospects for the economy in 1997. Things may go better than predicted or expected at the end of last year and early this year," Stals said.
Finance Minister Trevor Manuel, delivering the 1997/98 budget on Wednesday, said real gross domestic product was expected to grow by 2.5 percent in 1997, down from 3.1 percent in 1996.
